paragraph.content: has contravened a requirement imposed under a provision of this Ordinance (other than the provisions of Parts 2A and 3AA);

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: has, in relation to a PIE engagement completed on or after the 2019 Ordinance commencement date, done an act or made an omission that, in the AFRC’s opinion, is or is likely to be prejudicial to the interest of the investing public or the public interest; or

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: has done an act or made an omission that amounts to a practice irregularity within the meaning of section 4.

section.name: s37B
section.heading: FR misconduct by registered responsible persons
section.leadIn: For the purposes of this Ordinance, a registered responsible person of a registered PIE auditor has committed FR misconduct if the person— (Amended L.N. 66 of 2022)

paragraph.name: a
b
paragraph.content: has contravened a requirement imposed under a provision of this Ordinance (other than the provisions of Parts 2A and 3AA);

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: has, in relation to a PIE engagement completed by the auditor on or after the 2019 Ordinance commencement date, done an act or made an omission that, in the AFRC’s opinion, is or is likely to be prejudicial to the interest of the investing public or the public interest; or

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: has done an act or made an omission that amounts to a practice irregularity within the meaning of section 4.

section.name: s37C
section.heading: Whether act or omission likely to be prejudicial to interest of investing public etc.

subsection.content: In forming an opinion for section 37A(d) or 37B(c) about whether an act or omission is or is likely to be prejudicial to the interest of the investing public or the public interest, the AFRC must have regard to the provisions specified in subsection (2).

subsection.leadIn: The provisions are those set out in any code or guideline relating to the act or omission, which were published—

paragraph.name: a
b
paragraph.content: by the Securities and Futures Commission under the Securities and Futures Ordinance (Cap. 571);

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: by the HKEC under the Listing Rules; or

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: by the HKICPA under the PA Ordinance.

subsection.leadIn: The AFRC may impose one or more of the sanctions specified in subsection (2)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: on a professional person if the AFRC is satisfied that the person is guilty of CPA misconduct; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: on a person if the AFRC is satisfied that the person was guilty of CPA misconduct while being a professional person.

subsection.leadIn: The sanctions that may be imposed are—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to reprimand the person publicly or privately;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: subject to section 37H, to order the person to pay a pecuniary penalty not exceeding $500,000 to the AFRC;

paragraph.name: c
d
paragraph.leadIn: if the person is a professional person—

subparagraph.content: to revoke the person’s registration; or
to suspend the person’s registration for a period of time, or until the occurrence of an event, that the AFRC considers appropriate;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: if the person has a practising certificate—to cancel the practising certificate; and

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: to order that the person not be issued with a practising certificate either permanently or for a period of time that the AFRC considers appropriate.

subsection.content: If a person is ordered to pay any penalty, costs or expenses under this section, the AFRC may recover the penalty, costs or expenses from the person as a civil debt.

subsection.leadIn: If a certified public accountant’s registration is revoked or suspended under subsection (2)(d)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the AFRC must inform the HKICPA Registrar of the revocation or suspension; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: the HKICPA Registrar must—

subparagraph.content: remove the accountant’s name from the CPA register; and
for a suspension under subsection (2)(d)(ii)—restore the accountant’s name to the CPA register when the suspension ends.

subsection.leadIn: Nothing in this section requires the AFRC to inquire into the question whether a person was properly convicted of any offence, but the AFRC may consider—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the record of a case in which a conviction was recorded; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any other evidence that may show the nature and gravity of the offence.

section.name: s37D
section.heading: Sanctions for FR misconduct by PIE auditors

subsection.content: The AFRC may impose one or more of the sanctions specified in subsection (3) on a PIE auditor if the AFRC is satisfied that the auditor has committed FR misconduct.
The AFRC may impose one or more of the sanctions specified in subsection (3)(b) on a person if the AFRC is satisfied that the person committed FR misconduct while being a PIE auditor.

subsection.leadIn: The sanctions that may be imposed are—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: for a person who is a PIE auditor—

subparagraph.content: to revoke the person’s registration or recognition;
to suspend the person’s registration or recognition for a period of time, or until the occurrence of an event, that the AFRC considers appropriate; and
to impose a condition on the person’s registration or recognition; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: for a person who is or was a PIE auditor—

subparagraph.content: to reprimand the person publicly or privately;
to direct the person to carry out any remedial action specified by the AFRC;
to prohibit the person from applying to be registered or recognized as a PIE auditor for a period of time, or until the occurrence of an event, that the AFRC considers appropriate; and

subparagraph.leadIn: subject to section 37H, to order the person to pay a pecuniary penalty, not exceeding the amount which is the greater of—

subparagraph.name: B
subparagraph.content: 3 times the amount of the profit gained or loss avoided by the person as a result of the FR misconduct.

section.name: s37E
section.heading: Sanctions for FR misconduct by registered responsible persons

subsection.content: The AFRC may impose one or more of the sanctions specified in subsection (3) on a registered responsible person of a registered PIE auditor if the AFRC is satisfied that the person has committed FR misconduct.

The AFRC may impose one or more of the sanctions specified in subsection (3)(b) on a person if the AFRC is satisfied that the person committed FR misconduct while being a registered responsible person of a registered PIE auditor.

subsection.leadIn: The sanctions that may be imposed are—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: for a person who is a registered responsible person of a registered PIE auditor—to remove the person’s name from the list of registered responsible persons of the auditor, either—

subparagraph.content: permanently; or
for a period of time, or until the occurrence of an event, that the AFRC considers appropriate; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: for a person who is or was a registered responsible person of a registered PIE auditor—

subparagraph.content: to reprimand the person publicly or privately;
to direct the person to carry out any remedial action specified by the AFRC; and

subparagraph.leadIn: subject to section 37H, to order the person to pay a pecuniary penalty, not exceeding the amount which is the greater of—

subparagraph.name: B
subparagraph.content: 3 times the amount of the profit gained or loss avoided by the person as a result of the FR misconduct.

section.name: s37F
section.heading: Other cases in relation to PIE auditors and registered responsible persons

subsection.leadIn: The AFRC may impose a sanction under section 37D(3)(a)(i) or (ii) in relation to a registered PIE auditor if the AFRC is satisfied that— (Amended 41 of 2021 s. 65)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: for a registered PIE auditor who is a certified public accountant (practising)—

subparagraph.content: a bankruptcy order has been made against the auditor under the Bankruptcy Ordinance (Cap. 6);
the auditor has been convicted of an offence in Hong Kong or elsewhere that, in the AFRC’s opinion, impugns the fitness and properness of the auditor to remain registered; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: for a registered PIE auditor that is a firm of certified public accountants (practising)—

subparagraph.content: a partner of the auditor has entered into a voluntary arrangement with the partner’s creditors under the Bankruptcy Ordinance (Cap. 6);
a bankruptcy order has been made against a partner of the auditor under the Bankruptcy Ordinance (Cap. 6);
a partner of the auditor has been convicted of an offence in Hong Kong or elsewhere that, in the AFRC’s opinion, impugns the fitness and properness of the auditor to remain registered; or
a partner of the auditor has been found by a court to be mentally incapacitated, or has been detained in a mental hospital, under the Mental Health Ordinance (Cap. 136); or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: for a registered PIE auditor that is a corporate practice—

subparagraph.content: a receiver or manager has been appointed in relation to the property or business of the auditor;
the auditor has entered into a scheme of arrangement with its creditors;
the auditor has gone into liquidation;
the auditor has been convicted of an offence in Hong Kong or elsewhere that, in the AFRC’s opinion, impugns the fitness and properness of the auditor to remain registered;
a director of the auditor has been convicted of an offence in Hong Kong or elsewhere that, in the AFRC’s opinion, impugns the fitness and properness of the auditor to remain registered; or
a director of the auditor has been found by a court to be mentally incapacitated, or has been detained in a mental hospital, under the Mental Health Ordinance (Cap. 136).

subsection.leadIn: The AFRC may impose a sanction under section 37E(3)(a) in relation to a registered responsible person of a registered PIE auditor if the AFRC is satisfied that— (Amended 41 of 2021 s. 65)

paragraph.name: a
b
paragraph.content: a bankruptcy order has been made against the person under the Bankruptcy Ordinance (Cap. 6);

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the person has been convicted of an offence in Hong Kong or elsewhere that, in the AFRC’s opinion, impugns the fitness and properness of the person to remain a registered responsible person of the auditor; or

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: the person has been found by a court to be mentally incapacitated, or has been detained in a mental hospital, under the Mental Health Ordinance (Cap. 136).

subsection.content: The AFRC must not impose a sanction on a person under this Division without first giving the person a reasonable opportunity of being heard.
If the AFRC decides to impose a sanction on a person under this Division, the AFRC must, by written notice, inform the person of its decision.

subsection.leadIn: The notice must include—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a statement of the reasons for the decision;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the time when the decision is to take effect; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the details of the sanction imposed.

section.name: s37H
section.heading: Guidelines for exercise of power to impose pecuniary penalty

subsection.leadIn: The AFRC must not impose a pecuniary penalty under section 37CA(2)(b), 37D(3)(b)(iv) or 37E(3)(b)(iii) unless— (Amended 41 of 2021 s. 67)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: it has published, in the Gazette and in any other manner it considers appropriate, guidelines to indicate the way in which it exercises the power to impose the penalty; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: it has had regard to the guidelines so published in imposing the penalty.

subsection.content: The guidelines are not subsidiary legislation.

section.name: s37I
section.heading: AFRC’s power to take action in place of or in addition to imposing sanctions with consent

subsection.name: 1A
subsection.leadIn: At any time when the AFRC is contemplating whether to impose a sanction on a person under section 37CA, the AFRC may, with the person’s written consent—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: take any action referred to in section 37CA(2) in relation to the person; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: take any other action in relation to the person that the AFRC considers appropriate. (Added 41 of 2021 s. 68)

subsection.leadIn: At any time when the AFRC is contemplating whether to impose a sanction on a person under section 37D, 37E or 37F, the AFRC may, with the person’s written consent— (Amended 41 of 2021 s. 68)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: take any action referred to in section 37D(3) or 37E(3) in relation to the person; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: take any other action in relation to the person that the AFRC considers appropriate.

subsection.content: The AFRC may take an action under subsection (1A) or (1) in relation to the person in place of, or in addition to, imposing any sanction on the person under section 37CA, 37D, 37E or 37F.

subsection.leadIn: The AFRC may only take an action under subsection (1A) or (1) if it considers it appropriate to do so— (Amended 41 of 2021 s. 68)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in the interest of the investing public; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in the public interest.

subsection.content: Before taking any action under subsection (1A) or (1) in relation to the person, the AFRC must issue a written notice to the person, which must specify the action to be taken by the AFRC, and the time within which the action is to be taken, as consented to by the person.

subsection.leadIn: This section applies if the AFRC has made an order, requiring a person to pay a pecuniary penalty (pecuniary penalty order) under— (Amended 41 of 2021 s. 69)

paragraph.name: aa
paragraph.content: section 37CA(2)(b); (Added 41 of 2021 s. 69)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: section 37D(3)(b)(iv);

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: section 37E(3)(b)(iii); or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: section 37I(1A) or (1).

subsection.leadIn: The person must pay the penalty to the AFRC— (Amended 41 of 2021 s. 69)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: for a pecuniary penalty order under section 37CA(2)(b), 37D(3)(b)(iv) or 37E(3)(b)(iii)— (Amended 41 of 2021 s. 69)

subparagraph.content: within 30 days after the pecuniary penalty order has taken effect under section 37ZD; or
within a longer period specified in the notice issued under section 37G(2); or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: for a pecuniary penalty order under section 37I(1A) or (1)—within the time specified in the notice issued under section 37I(4).

subsection.content: The Court of First Instance may, on application by the AFRC, register the pecuniary penalty order.
The application must be accompanied by a copy of the notice issued under section 37G(2) or 37I(4), as the case requires.
On registration, the pecuniary penalty order is to be regarded as an order of the Court of First Instance made within the civil jurisdiction of the Court of First Instance for the payment of money.
Any money paid to or recovered by the AFRC under the pecuniary penalty order must be paid into the general revenue.

subsection.leadIn: This section applies if the AFRC has, in relation to a person— (Amended 41 of 2021 s. 70)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: imposed any sanction under section 37CA, 37D, 37E or 37F; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: taken any action under section 37I.

subsection.leadIn: The AFRC must disclose to the public— (Amended 41 of 2021 s. 70)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the material facts relating to the case;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: its decision to impose a sanction or take an action, and the reasons for the decision; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the sanction imposed or action taken.

subsection.leadIn: The disclosure may only be made after—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: for a case where a sanction is imposed—

subparagraph.content: the expiry of the period for lodging an application for review to the Tribunal in relation to the AFRC’s decision; or
if such an application is lodged, the review has been disposed of; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: for a case where an action is taken—the notice under section 37I(4) is issued to the person concerned.

subsection.leadIn: The AFRC must not make any disclosure under subsection (2) if— (Amended 41 of 2021 s. 70)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the disclosure relates to a private reprimand under section 37CA(2)(a), 37D(3)(b)(i) or 37E(3)(b)(i);

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the disclosure may adversely affect any criminal proceedings before a court or magistrate; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the disclosure, in the AFRC’s opinion, is not in the interest of the investing public or in the public interest.

section.name: s37L
section.heading: AFRC may have regard to any information or material when making decisions
section.content: In deciding whether to exercise a power under this Part, the AFRC may have regard to any information or material in its possession that is relevant to the decision, regardless of how the information or material has come into its possession.

part.name: P3C
part.heading: Reviews and Appeals Regarding Decisions on Certified Public Accountants, Practice Units and PIE Auditors etc.

section.name: s37M
section.heading: Interpretation
section.leadIn: In this Part—
section.def: leave application (許可申請) means an application made under section 37ZG;

specified period (指明限期), in relation to a specified decision, means the period of 21 days beginning on the day after the notice of the decision is issued by the decision authority to the person in relation to whom the decision is made. (Amended 41 of 2021 s. 73)

division.name: D2
division.heading: Accounting and Financial Reporting Review Tribunal

section.name: s37N
section.heading: Accounting and Financial Reporting Review Tribunal

subsection.leadIn: On and after the 2021 Ordinance commencement date, the tribunal established under the former section 37N(1) and known as the “Public Interest Entities Auditors Review Tribunal” in English and “公眾利益實體核數師覆核審裁處” in Chinese immediately before that date is known as—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the “Accounting and Financial Reporting Review Tribunal” in English; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: “會計及財務匯報覆核審裁處” in Chinese. (Replaced 41 of 2021 s. 75)

subsection.name: 1A
subsection.leadIn: Despite the repeal of the former section 37N(1)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the tribunal established under that section continues in existence as the Tribunal on and after the 2021 Ordinance commencement date; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: accordingly, the jurisdiction, powers, functions and duties of that tribunal are not affected in any way by the change of name effected by subsection (1). (Added 41 of 2021 s. 75)

subsection.name: 1B
subsection.content: To avoid doubt, the repeal of the former section 37N(1) or the change of name effected by subsection (1) does not affect any power exercised or function or duty performed by that tribunal before the 2021 Ordinance commencement date. (Added 41 of 2021 s. 75)

subsection.leadIn: The Tribunal—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: consists of a chairperson and 2 other members; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: is presided over by the chairperson.

subsection.content: Schedule 4A has effect with respect to the Tribunal.

subsection.leadIn: In this section—
subsection.def: former section 37N(1) (原有第37N(1)條) means section 37N(1) as in force immediately before the 2021 Ordinance commencement date. (Added 41 of 2021 s. 75)

section.name: s37O
section.heading: Jurisdiction of Tribunal
section.leadIn: The Tribunal has jurisdiction, in accordance with this Part and Schedule 4A—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to review any specified decision; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: to hear and determine a question or issue arising out of, or in connection with, a review of a specified decision.

subsection.content: If the Chief Executive considers it appropriate to do so, the Chief Executive may establish additional tribunals for any review over which the Tribunal has jurisdiction.
This Ordinance applies, with necessary modifications, to each of the additional tribunals as it applies to the Tribunal.

section.name: s37Q
section.heading: Application for review of specified decision

subsection.content: Subject to section 37R, a person who is aggrieved by a specified decision made in relation to the person may, at any time within the specified period, apply to the Tribunal for a review of the decision.

subsection.leadIn: The application—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: must be in writing; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: must state the grounds for the application.

subsection.leadIn: The Tribunal must, as soon as practicable after receiving the application, send a copy of the application to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the decision authority; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if the decision authority is the HKICPA Council, the AFRC. (Amended 41 of 2021 s. 105)

section.name: s37R
section.heading: Extension of time for review application

subsection.content: The Tribunal may, on the written application within the specified period by a person aggrieved by a specified decision made in relation to the person, by order extend the time for making a review application in relation to the decision.
Before deciding whether to grant an extension of time, the Tribunal must give the person who made the application and the decision authority a reasonable opportunity of being heard.
The Tribunal may grant an extension of time if it is satisfied that there is a good cause for doing so.
A person who has made a review application may withdraw the application by written notice to the Tribunal.
The withdrawal may be made at any time before the hearing of the review.
The Tribunal may make an order for costs in relation to a review application and its withdrawal that the Tribunal considers appropriate.

subsection.leadIn: The Tribunal may determine a review in relation to a specified decision by—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: confirming, varying or setting aside the decision; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: remitting the matter in question to the decision authority with any direction it considers appropriate.

subsection.content: If a specified decision is set aside, the Tribunal may make another decision it considers appropriate (new decision) in substitution for the specified decision.

subsection.leadIn: A varied or new decision made by the Tribunal under subsection (1)(a) or (2)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: may only be one that the decision authority had power to make in relation to the applicant for the review application, whether or not under the same provision under which the original specified decision was made; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: may be more or less onerous than the original specified decision.

subsection.content: In reviewing a specified decision, the Tribunal must give the parties to the review a reasonable opportunity of being heard.
The standard of proof required to determine any question or issue before the Tribunal is the standard of proof applicable to civil proceedings in a court of law.

subsection.leadIn: Subject to Schedule 4A, the Tribunal may, for the purpose of a review, on its own initiative or on application by a party to the review—

paragraph.name: a
b
paragraph.content: determine the way in which any material mentioned in paragraph (a) is received;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: by written notice signed by the chairperson of the Tribunal, require a person—

subparagraph.content: to attend before it at any sitting and to give evidence; and
to produce any article, record or document in the person’s possession or control relating to the subject matter of the review;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: administer oaths;

paragraph.name: e
f
paragraph.content: order a witness to give evidence by affidavit;

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.content: order a person not to publish or otherwise disclose any material the Tribunal receives;

paragraph.name: h
j
paragraph.content: determine the procedure to be followed in the review; and

paragraph.name: k
paragraph.content: exercise any other powers or make any other orders that may be necessary for, or ancillary to, the conduct of the review or the performance of the Tribunal’s functions.

subsection.leadIn: A person commits an offence if the person, without reasonable excuse—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: fails to comply with an order, notice, prohibition or requirement of the Tribunal made, given or imposed under subsection (1);

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: disrupts any sitting of the Tribunal or otherwise misbehaves during any sitting of the Tribunal;

paragraph.name: c
d
e
paragraph.content: threatens, insults or causes any loss to be suffered by a person who has attended before the Tribunal, on account of the attendance; or

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: threatens, insults or causes any loss to be suffered by the chairperson, or any other member, of the Tribunal at any time, on account of the performance of the chairperson’s or member’s functions.

subsection.leadIn: A person who commits an offence under subsection (2) is liable—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: on conviction on indictment—to a fine of $1,000,000 and to imprisonment for 2 years; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: on summary conviction—to a fine at level 6 and to imprisonment for 6 months.

subsection.content: A person is not excused from complying with an order, notice, prohibition or requirement of the Tribunal made, given or imposed under subsection (1) only on the ground that to do so might tend to incriminate the person.

section.name: s37V
section.heading: Sittings of Tribunal to be held in public

subsection.content: Every sitting of the Tribunal for determining a review must be held in public.

Subsection (1) does not apply if the Tribunal, on its own initiative or on application by a party to the review, determines that a sitting, or any part of a sitting, must be held in private in the interests of justice.
The hearing of an application mentioned in subsection (2) must be held in private.

section.name: s37W
section.heading: Use of incriminating evidence given for purpose of review

subsection.leadIn: This section applies if the Tribunal—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: requires a person to give evidence under section 37U(1)(c)(i);

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: requires a person to answer any question under section 37U(1)(e);

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: orders a person to give evidence under section 37U(1)(f); or

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: otherwise requires or orders a person to provide any information under section 37U(1)(k).

subsection.content: A person is not excused from complying with the requirement or order of the Tribunal only on the ground that the evidence, answer or information might tend to incriminate the person.
However, subsection (4) applies if the evidence, answer or information might tend to incriminate the person.

Despite anything in this Ordinance and subject to subsection (5), neither the evidence, answer or information given or provided by the person, nor the requirement or order of the Tribunal, is admissible in evidence against the person in criminal proceedings in a court of law.

subsection.leadIn: Subsection (4) does not apply to criminal proceedings in which the person is charged, in relation to the evidence, answer or information, with an offence under—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: section 37U(2)(a); or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: Part V of the Crimes Ordinance (Cap. 200).

subsection.content: The Tribunal has the same powers as the Court of First Instance to punish for contempt.

Without limiting subsection (1), the Tribunal may punish for contempt a person who, without reasonable excuse, engages in conduct falling within section 37U(2) as if the conduct were a contempt of court and the Tribunal were the Court of First Instance.
The Tribunal must, in exercising its powers to punish for contempt, adopt the standard of proof the Court of First Instance would adopt in exercising the same powers.

subsection.leadIn: The Tribunal may, in relation to a review, by order award to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a person whose attendance, whether or not as a witness, has been necessary or required for the purpose of the review; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a party to the review,

subsection.continued: a sum it considers appropriate in respect of the costs reasonably incurred by the person or party in relation to the review.

subsection.leadIn: The costs awarded must be paid by, and are recoverable as a civil debt from—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: if they are awarded to a person under subsection (1)(a)—a party to the review that the Tribunal considers appropriate; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if they are awarded to a party to the review under subsection (1)(b)—the other party to the review.

subsection.content: Subject to any rules made by the Chief Justice under section 37ZJ, Order 62 of the Rules of the High Court (Cap. 4 sub. leg. A) applies to the award of costs, and to the taxation of any costs awarded, by the Tribunal under subsection (1).

subsection.leadIn: The Tribunal must, as soon as practicable after determining a review, issue to each party to the review—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: its determination and the reasons for the determination; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any order made under section 37Y(1) for costs (costs order) and the reasons for the order.

subsection.content: If the review is made in relation to a specified decision by the HKICPA Council, the Tribunal must also issue to the AFRC the determination and costs order, and the reasons for the determination and order. (Amended 41 of 2021 s. 105)

If a sitting of the Tribunal, or a part of it, is held in private, the Tribunal may by order prohibit the publication or disclosure, wholly or partly, of the determination or costs order, or the reasons for the determination or order.
A person commits an offence if the person, without reasonable excuse, fails to comply with an order of the Tribunal made under subsection (3).

subsection.leadIn: A person who commits an offence under subsection (4) is liable—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: on conviction on indictment—to a fine of $1,000,000 and to imprisonment for 2 years; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: on summary conviction—to a fine at level 6 and to imprisonment for 6 months.

section.name: s37ZA
section.heading: Form and proof of determination or order of Tribunal

subsection.leadIn: A determination or order made by the Tribunal must—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: be in writing; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: be signed by the chairperson of the Tribunal.

subsection.leadIn: A document purporting to be a determination or order of the Tribunal and signed by the chairperson of the Tribunal is, in the absence of evidence to the contrary, presumed to be a determination or order of the Tribunal duly made and signed—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: without proof of its making;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: without proof of the signature; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: without proof that the person signing the determination or order was in fact the chairperson of the Tribunal.

section.name: s37ZB
section.heading: Registration of determination or order of Tribunal

subsection.content: The Court of First Instance may, on written notice given by the Tribunal in the way prescribed by rules made by the Chief Justice under section 37ZJ, register a determination or order of the Tribunal.
A determination or order so registered is to be regarded, for its enforcement, as a determination or order of the Court of First Instance made within its jurisdiction.

section.name: s37ZC
section.heading: No other right of appeal
section.content: Subject to section 50 of the High Court Ordinance (Cap. 4) and section 37ZF, a determination or order of the Tribunal is final and is not subject to appeal.

division.name: D4
division.heading: Taking Effect of Specified Decisions and Stay of Execution of Determinations or Orders of Tribunal

section.name: s37ZD
section.heading: Time when specified decision takes effect

subsection.leadIn: Subject to subsection (2), a specified decision takes effect—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: if, before the expiry of the specified period, the person in relation to whom the decision is made notifies the decision authority in writing that the person will not make a review application—on the day after the authority is notified;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: subject to paragraph (a), if the person does not make a review application within the specified period, including any extension of time granted by the Tribunal under section 37R—on the day after the period expires; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: if the person makes a review application—

subparagraph.content: if the decision is confirmed by the Tribunal—on the day after the decision is confirmed;
if the decision is varied, or substituted by another decision, by the Tribunal—on the day after the decision is varied or substituted, subject to the terms of the variation or substitution; or
if the application is withdrawn—on the day after the application is withdrawn.

subsection.content: The decision authority may specify any other day on which a specified decision is to take effect, if it considers it appropriate in the public interest to do so.

section.name: s37ZE
section.heading: Application for stay of execution of determination or order of Tribunal

subsection.content: A party to a review may, at any time after the review is determined by the Tribunal, apply to the Tribunal for a stay of execution of the determination, or of an order, made by the Tribunal.
On an application under subsection (1), the Tribunal may, if it considers it appropriate to do so, order a stay of execution of the determination or of the order.
The Tribunal may attach any condition it considers appropriate to an order made under subsection (2), including any condition as to costs or payment of money into the Tribunal.

section.name: s37ZF
section.heading: Party may appeal against Tribunal’s determination

subsection.leadIn: If a party to a review is dissatisfied with a determination of the review made by the Tribunal, the party may appeal to the Court of Appeal against the determination on—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a question of law;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a question of fact; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: a question of mixed law and fact.

subsection.content: No appeal may be made under subsection (1) unless leave to appeal has been granted by the Court of Appeal.

A party to a review may apply to the Court of Appeal for leave to appeal against a determination of the review made by the Tribunal within 30 days after the day on which the determination is issued to the party.
The Court of Appeal may, on application by a party to a review, extend the time within which a leave application may be made.

subsection.leadIn: The leave to appeal may be granted—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in relation to a particular issue arising out of a determination by the Tribunal; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: subject to any condition that the Court of Appeal considers necessary in order to secure the just, expeditious and economical disposal of the appeal.

subsection.leadIn: The leave to appeal may only be granted if the Court of Appeal is satisfied that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the appeal has a reasonable prospect of success; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: there is some other reason in the interests of justice why the appeal should be heard.

subsection.content: The Court of Appeal may determine a leave application without a hearing on the basis of written submissions only.
No appeal lies from a decision of the Court of Appeal as to whether leave to appeal to it should be granted.

subsection.leadIn: The Court of Appeal may, on an appeal against a determination of the Tribunal—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: allow the appeal;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: dismiss the appeal;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: vary or set aside the determination; or

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: remit the matter in question to the Tribunal or to the decision authority with any direction it considers appropriate.

subsection.content: If a determination of the Tribunal is set aside, the Court of Appeal may make another determination it considers appropriate (new determination) in substitution for the determination.

subsection.leadIn: A varied or new determination made by the Court of Appeal under subsection (1)(c) or (2)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: may only be one that the Tribunal had power to make in relation to the review in question; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: may be more or less onerous than the Tribunal’s original determination.

subsection.content: In an appeal under this section, the Court of Appeal may make any order for costs it considers appropriate.

section.name: s37ZI
section.heading: No stay of execution of Tribunal’s determination on appeal

subsection.content: Without prejudice to section 37ZE, the making of an appeal under section 37ZF against a determination of the Tribunal does not by itself operate as a stay of execution of the determination.
However, a party to the appeal may apply to the Court of Appeal for a stay of execution of the determination of the Tribunal.
On an application under subsection (2), the Court of Appeal may, if it considers it appropriate to do so, order a stay of execution of the determination of the Tribunal.
The Court of Appeal may attach any condition it considers appropriate to an order made under subsection (3), including any condition as to costs or payment of money into the Court.

section.name: s37ZJ
section.heading: Power of Chief Justice to make rules
section.leadIn: The Chief Justice may make rules—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: providing for the award of costs under section 37Y and the taxation of those costs;

paragraph.name: b
c
paragraph.leadIn: regulating—

subparagraph.content: the procedures for the hearing of appeals under section 37ZF; and

paragraph.name: d
e
f
paragraph.content: providing for the issue or service (however described) of any document under this Part or Schedule 4A; and

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.content: prescribing a matter that, as provided for in this Part, is to be or may be prescribed by rules made by the Chief Justice.

subsection.def: In this Part, enquirer (查訊機構) means, subject to subsection (2), the AFRC. (Amended 3 of 2019 s. 49; 41 of 2021 s. 105)

subsection.content: If a Review Committee is appointed under section 40(1)(b) to make an enquiry concerning a relevant non-compliance, a reference to enquirer means, for the purpose of the non-compliance, the Committee.

The Chief Executive must, in consultation with the AFRC, appoint a Financial Reporting Review Panel of at least 20 persons, whom the Chief Executive considers suitable for appointment under section 40(1)(b) as members of a Review Committee either because of their experience in accounting, auditing, finance, banking, law, administration or management, or because of their professional or occupational experience. (Amended 41 of 2021 s. 105)
The Chief Executive must appoint, from amongst the members of the Review Panel, at least 3 Panel Convenors.
The Chief Executive must give notice of each appointment under subsection (1) or (2) by notice published in the Gazette.
Schedule 5 has effect with respect to the Review Panel and its members.

subsection.leadIn: If it appears to the AFRC that there is or may be a question whether or not there is a relevant non-compliance in relation to a listed entity, and the AFRC certifies in writing to that effect— (Amended 3 of 2019 s. 51; 41 of 2021 s. 105)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the AFRC may, for the purpose of enquiring into the non-compliance or the question, exercise the powers under Division 2; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: the AFRC may appoint a Financial Reporting Review Committee consisting of— (Amended 3 of 2019 s. 51; 41 of 2021 s. 105)

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: a Panel Convenor appointed under section 39(2), who is to be the chairperson of the Review Committee; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: at least 4 other members of the Review Panel,

paragraph.continued: to enquire, with those powers, into the non-compliance and the question.

subsection.content: On making an appointment under subsection (1)(b), the AFRC must notify the listed entity in writing of the names of the members of the Review Committee.
The AFRC must, on making an appointment under subsection (1)(b), specify the terms of reference of the Review Committee, and the Committee must act in accordance with those terms.

If a Review Committee is appointed to make an enquiry concerning a relevant non-compliance, the AFRC must not, for the purpose of enquiring into the non-compliance or the question whether or not there is such a non-compliance, exercise the powers under Division 2.

subsection.leadIn: A Review Committee may perform any of its functions, and its proceedings are valid, despite—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a vacancy in the membership of the Committee;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a defect in the appointment or qualification of a person purporting to be a member of the Review Panel or the Committee; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: a minor irregularity in the convening of any meeting of the Committee.

subsection.content: Schedule 6 has effect with respect to a Review Committee and its members.

section.name: s42
section.heading: AFRC to notify certain bodies of powers under Division 2 being exercisable

subsection.content: If the AFRC certifies under section 40(1) that it appears to the AFRC that there is or may be a question whether or not there is a relevant non-compliance in relation to a listed entity to which this section applies, the AFRC must give a written notice in accordance with subsections (3) and (4). (Amended 3 of 2019 s. 52; 41 of 2021 s. 76)

subsection.leadIn: This section applies to a listed entity—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: that—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: is an authorized institution; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.leadIn: to the AFRC’s knowledge— (Amended 3 of 2019 s. 52; 41 of 2021 s. 76)

subparagraph.name: A
subparagraph.content: is a controller of an authorized institution;

subparagraph.name: B
subparagraph.content: has as its controller an authorized institution; or

subparagraph.name: C
subparagraph.content: has a controller that is also a controller of an authorized institution;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: that is an insurer authorized under the Insurance Ordinance (Cap. 41); (Amended 12 of 2015 s. 151)

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: that is—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: a licensed person within the meaning of section 1 of Part 1 of Schedule 1 to the Securities and Futures Ordinance (Cap. 571); or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: a collective investment scheme authorized under section 104 of that Ordinance; or

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: that is an approved trustee within the meaning of section 2(1) of the Mandatory Provident Fund Schemes Ordinance (Cap. 485).

subsection.leadIn: The notice is to be given to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in the case of a listed entity that falls within subsection (2)(a), the Monetary Authority;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in the case of a listed entity that falls within subsection (2)(b), the Insurance Authority;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: in the case of a listed entity that falls within subsection (2)(c), the Securities and Futures Commission;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: in the case of a listed entity that falls within subsection (2)(d), the Mandatory Provident Fund Schemes Authority.

subsection.content: The notice is to specify that the powers under Division 2 are exercisable for the purpose of enquiring into the relevant non-compliance or the question whether or not there is such a non-compliance.

division.name: D2
division.heading: Powers for the purpose of enquiry

section.name: s43
section.heading: Powers to require production of records and documents and provision of information and explanation

subsection.leadIn: The enquirer may, in writing, require—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: where the listed entity is a listed corporation, the listed corporation;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: where the listed entity is a listed collective investment scheme, a person who is, or was at the material time, a responsible person of the listed collective investment scheme;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: a relevant undertaking of the listed entity;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: a person who is, or was at the material time, an auditor of the corporation, scheme or undertaking; or

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: a person who is, or was at the material time, an officer or employee of the corporation, responsible person or undertaking,

subsection.continued: to produce or give, within the time and at the place specified in the requirement, any record or document, or any information or explanation, specified in the requirement if the enquirer has reasonable cause to believe, and certifies in writing that it has reasonable cause to believe, that the record or document, or the information or explanation, is relevant to the relevant non-compliance or to the question whether or not there is such a non-compliance.

subsection.leadIn: The enquirer must not impose a requirement on a person under subsection (1) unless, before doing so, the enquirer has consulted— (Amended 3 of 2019 s. 53)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: if the person—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: is an authorized institution; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.leadIn: to the AFRC’s knowledge— (Amended 3 of 2019 s. 53; 41 of 2021 s. 77)

subparagraph.name: A
subparagraph.content: is a controller of an authorized institution;

subparagraph.name: B
subparagraph.content: has as its controller an authorized institution; or

subparagraph.name: C
subparagraph.content: has a controller that is also a controller of an authorized institution,

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if the person is an insurer authorized under the Insurance Ordinance (Cap. 41), the Insurance Authority; (Amended 12 of 2015 s. 152)

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: if the person is—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: a licensed person within the meaning of section 1 of Part 1 of Schedule 1 to the Securities and Futures Ordinance (Cap. 571); or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: a responsible person of a collective investment scheme authorized under section 104 of that Ordinance,

paragraph.continued: the Securities and Futures Commission; and

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: if the person is an approved trustee within the meaning of section 2(1) of the Mandatory Provident Fund Schemes Ordinance (Cap. 485), the Mandatory Provident Fund Schemes Authority.

subsection.content: A person is not excused from complying with a requirement imposed on the person under subsection (1) only on the ground that to do so might tend to incriminate the person. (Amended 3 of 2019 s. 53)

section.name: s44
section.heading: Use of incriminating evidence in proceedings

subsection.content: If the enquirer requires a person to give any information or explanation under section 43(1), the enquirer must ensure that the person has first been informed or reminded of the limitations imposed by subsection (2) on the admissibility in evidence of the requirement and of the information or explanation.

subsection.leadIn: Despite anything in this Ordinance, if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the enquirer requires a person to give any information or explanation under section 43(1); and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the information or explanation might tend to incriminate the person, and the person so claims before giving the information or explanation,

subsection.continued: the requirement, as well as the information or explanation, are not admissible in evidence against the person in criminal proceedings in a court of law other than those in which the person is charged with an offence under Part V of the Crimes Ordinance (Cap. 200) in respect of the information or explanation.

section.name: s45
section.heading: Powers of Court of First Instance in relation to failure to comply with requirements under section 43

subsection.content: If a person fails to comply with a requirement imposed on the person under section 43, the enquirer may, by originating summons, request the Court of First Instance to exercise the powers under subsection (2).

subsection.leadIn: The Court of First Instance may— (Amended 3 of 2019 s. 55)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: on being satisfied that there is no reasonable excuse for the person not to comply with the requirement, order the person to comply with the requirement within the period specified by the Court; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: on being satisfied that the failure was without reasonable excuse, punish the person, and any other person knowingly involved in the failure, in the same manner as if the person and, if applicable, that other person had been guilty of contempt of court.

subsection.content: An originating summons under subsection (1) is to be in Form No. 10 in Appendix A to the Rules of the High Court (Cap. 4 sub. leg. A).

section.name: s46
section.heading: Inspection of records or documents seized, etc.
section.content: If the enquirer has taken possession of any record or document under this Division, the enquirer must, subject to any reasonable conditions the enquirer imposes as to security or otherwise, permit a person who would be entitled to inspect the record or document had the enquirer not taken possession of it under this Division, to inspect it and to make copies or otherwise record details of it at all reasonable times.

subsection.content: As soon as practicable after the completion of an enquiry under this Part, the enquirer must prepare a written report on the findings of the enquiry.

The enquirer may, if it thinks fit, prepare an interim report on the enquiry. But if the enquirer falls within section 38(2), the enquirer must also prepare an interim report on the enquiry as soon as practicable after being required by the AFRC to do so.
The AFRC may adopt a report prepared under subsection (1) or (2).

If, in the AFRC’s opinion, any person named in a report prepared under subsection (1) or (2) would in the event of a publication or other disclosure of the report, or any part of the report, be adversely affected by the publication or disclosure, the enquirer must, before the report is adopted under subsection (3), first give the person a reasonable opportunity of being heard.
After having adopted a report under subsection (3), the AFRC may publish or otherwise disclose the report or any part of it.

subsection.leadIn: In deciding whether to publish or otherwise disclose the report or any part of it, the AFRC must take into account— (Amended 41 of 2021 s. 78)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: whether the publication or disclosure may adversely affect any of the following proceedings that have been, or are likely to be, instituted—

subparagraph.content: any proceedings under Part 3C;
any criminal proceedings before a court or magistrate;
any proceedings before the Market Misconduct Tribunal;
any proceedings before a Disciplinary Committee constituted under section 33(3) of the PA Ordinance as in force immediately before the 2021 Ordinance commencement date; (Added 41 of 2021 s. 78)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: whether the publication or disclosure may adversely affect any person named in the report; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: whether the publication or disclosure would be in the interest of the investing public or in the public interest. (Replaced 3 of 2019 s. 57)

subsection.leadIn: A document purporting—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to be a copy of a report adopted under subsection (3); and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: to be certified by the chairperson of the AFRC as a true copy of such a report,

subsection.continued: is, on its production without further proof, admissible as evidence of the facts stated in the report in any of the proceedings specified in subsection (8). (Replaced 3 of 2019 s. 57)

subsection.leadIn: The proceedings are—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: proceedings under Part 3C;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: civil proceedings before a court;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: proceedings before the Market Misconduct Tribunal;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: proceedings under section 41 of the PA Ordinance; or (Replaced 41 of 2021 s. 78)

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: proceedings before a Disciplinary Committee constituted under section 33(3) of the PA Ordinance as in force immediately before the 2021 Ordinance commencement date. (Added 41 of 2021 s. 78)

section.name: s48
section.heading: AFRC’s powers to close case, suspend enquiry and follow up, etc.

subsection.leadIn: The AFRC may, in relation to an enquiry under this Part concerning a relevant non-compliance— (Amended 3 of 2019 s. 58; 41 of 2021 s. 79)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: close the case without further action;

paragraph.name: b
c
paragraph.content: secure the removal of the non-compliance in accordance with Division 4; or

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: carry out such other follow-up action in accordance with this Ordinance as the AFRC thinks fit.

subsection.content: The AFRC must not, in relation to an enquiry under this Part, exercise a power under subsection (1) unless the AFRC has taken into account the report prepared under section 47(1) or (2) in relation to the enquiry.

As soon as practicable after deciding to exercise a power under subsection (1), the AFRC must give written notice of the decision to the listed entity concerned unless the AFRC is satisfied that the notification may prejudice the enquiry, or any other action by the AFRC, or a specified body, relating to the enquiry.

division.name: D4
division.heading: AFRC’s powers to secure removal of relevant non-compliance

section.name: s49
section.heading: AFRC to give notice to operator of listed entities to secure removal of relevant non-compliance

subsection.content: If, after the AFRC has taken into account a report prepared under section 47(1) or (2) for an enquiry concerning a relevant non-compliance in relation to a listed entity, it appears to the AFRC that there is or may be a question whether or not there is such a relevant non-compliance, the AFRC may give a written notice to the operator of the listed entity in accordance with subsection (2).

subsection.leadIn: The notice is to—

paragraph.name: a
b
paragraph.leadIn: specify—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: such manner of revising the relevant financial report of the listed entity as the AFRC thinks fit; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: such other remedial action concerning that report as the AFRC thinks fit; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: specify a period for the operator to—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: give a satisfactory explanation of the relevant financial report of the entity;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: cause that report to be revised in such manner as specified in the notice; or

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: take such other remedial action concerning that report as specified in the notice.

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in relation to a listed corporation, means the directors of the corporation;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in relation to a listed collective investment scheme, means the manager of the scheme.

section.name: s50
section.heading: AFRC may apply to Court of First Instance to secure removal of relevant non-compliance

subsection.leadIn: This section applies if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the AFRC gives a notice to the directors of a listed corporation under section 49(1); and (Amended 3 of 2019 s. 61; 41 of 2021 s. 82)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: at the end of the period specified in the notice, or such longer period as the AFRC may allow, it appears to the AFRC that the directors have not— (Amended 3 of 2019 s. 61; 41 of 2021 s. 82)

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: given a satisfactory explanation of the relevant financial report of the corporation;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: caused that report to be revised in such manner as specified in the notice; or

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: taken such other remedial action concerning that report as specified in the notice.

subsection.leadIn: The AFRC may, by originating summons, apply to the Court of First Instance for— (Amended 3 of 2019 s. 61; 41 of 2021 s. 82)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a declaration that there is a relevant non-compliance in relation to the listed corporation; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: an order requiring the directors of the corporation to—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: cause the relevant financial report of the corporation to be revised in such manner as the Court considers necessary; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: take such other remedial action concerning that report as the Court considers necessary,

paragraph.continued: within the period specified in the order.

subsection.content: An originating summons under subsection (2) is to be in Form No. 10 in Appendix A to the Rules of the High Court (Cap. 4 sub. leg. A).

subsection.leadIn: On making an application under subsection (2), the AFRC must deliver— (Amended 3 of 2019 s. 61; 41 of 2021 s. 82)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a copy of the notice of application; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a statement setting out the grounds for the application and the matter at issue in the proceedings,

subsection.continued: to the Securities and Futures Commission, and to the Registrar of Companies for registration.

subsection.leadIn: If the Court of First Instance makes an order under subsection (2)(b), it may also give directions with respect to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the audit of the accounts constituting the relevant financial report that has been revised pursuant to the order;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the revision of the directors’ report, or summary financial report, relating to the relevant financial report;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the steps to be taken by the directors of the listed corporation to bring the order to the attention of those who are likely to rely on, or have relied on, the relevant financial report; or

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: such other matters as the Court thinks fit.

subsection.leadIn: If the Court of First Instance makes a declaration and order under subsection (2), it may also order all or part of any of the costs and expenses set out in subsection (7)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to be borne by the directors of the listed corporation who were party to the approval of the relevant financial report; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: to be recoverable from those directors as a civil debt.

subsection.leadIn: The costs and expenses referred to in subsection (6) are—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the costs and expenses of and incidental to the application;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in the case where the AFRC has enquired into, or has appointed a Review Committee to enquire into, the relevant non-compliance or the question whether or not there is such a non-compliance, the costs and expenses of and incidental to the enquiry; and (Amended 3 of 2019 s. 61; 41 of 2021 s. 82)

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the costs and expenses incurred by the listed corporation in connection with, or in consequence of, revising the relevant financial report or carrying out remedies to the report.

subsection.leadIn: If the Court of First Instance makes an order under subsection (6)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: it must have regard to whether each of the directors who were party to the approval of the relevant financial report knew, or ought to have known, that the report did not comply with any relevant requirement; and (Amended 3 of 2019 s. 61)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: it may exclude one or more directors from the order or order the payment of different amounts by different directors.

subsection.leadIn: On the conclusion of proceedings on an application under subsection (2), the AFRC must deliver— (Amended 3 of 2019 s. 61; 41 of 2021 s. 82)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a sealed copy of the declaration, order, direction or other determination made by the Court of First Instance; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a notice that the application has failed or been withdrawn,

subsection.continued: to the Securities and Futures Commission, and to the Registrar of Companies for registration.

subsection.content: For the purposes of this section, the directors of a listed corporation at the time when the relevant financial report of the corporation was approved by them, except a director of the corporation who shows that the director took all reasonable steps to prevent the report from being so approved, were party to the approval of that report. (Amended 3 of 2019 s. 61)

section.name: s50A
section.heading: Levies payable by sellers and purchasers of securities

subsection.content: A levy, calculated in accordance with section 1 of Schedule 7, is payable by the seller and purchaser in a sale and purchase of securities that is recorded on a recognized stock market or notified to a recognized exchange company under its rules.
A person who is liable to pay a levy under subsection (1) must pay the levy to the HKEC in the way and within the time specified by the HKEC.

subsection.leadIn: The HKEC must pay the levy collected into a bank account specified by the AFRC on— (Amended 41 of 2021 s. 105)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the 15th day of the month following the month in which the levy is collected; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if the 15th day is not a business day, the next business day.

subsection.leadIn: The HKEC must keep—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: proper accounts of all transactions for which a levy is payable under subsection (1); and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: proper accounts relating to the collection and payment of levies.

subsection.leadIn: In this section—
subsection.def: rules (規章), in relation to a recognized exchange company, has the meaning given by section 1 of Part 1 of Schedule 1 to the Securities and Futures Ordinance (Cap. 571).

subsection.content: A levy, calculated in accordance with section 2 of Schedule 7, is payable by a PIE for a calendar year.
A PIE must pay the levy to the HKEC in the way and within the time specified by the HKEC.
The HKEC must pay the levy collected into a bank account specified by the AFRC within 30 days after its collection. (Amended 41 of 2021 s. 105)
The HKEC must keep proper accounts relating to the collection and payment of levies.
A levy, calculated in accordance with section 3 of Schedule 7, is payable by a PIE auditor for a calendar year.
A PIE auditor must provide the AFRC with the information or document that the AFRC reasonably requires for ascertaining the levy payable by the auditor. (Amended 41 of 2021 s. 83)
A PIE auditor must pay the levy to the AFRC in the way and within the time specified by the AFRC. (Amended 41 of 2021 s. 83)

If, during a financial year of the AFRC, the conditions set out in subsection (2) are satisfied, the AFRC must consult the Financial Secretary with a view to recommending to the Chief Executive in Council that the rate or amount of a levy payable under this Part be reduced.

subsection.leadIn: The conditions are—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: that the reserves of the AFRC, after deducting depreciation and all provisions, are more than twice its estimated operating expenses for the financial year; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: that the AFRC has no outstanding debt.

subsection.content: The AFRC may, after consulting the Financial Secretary under subsection (1), recommend to the Chief Executive in Council that the rate or amount of a levy payable under this Part be reduced.

section.name: s50E
section.heading: Levies paid not refundable
section.content: Levies paid under this Part are not refundable.

section.name: s50F
section.heading: AFRC may recover levy as civil debt
section.content: The AFRC may recover the amount of any levy payable under this Part as a civil debt due to it.

section.name: s50G
section.heading: AFRC may authorize persons to inspect accounts etc.

subsection.content: For ascertaining whether the HKEC is complying with or has complied with a provision under this Part, the AFRC may, in writing, authorize a person to, at reasonable times, inspect and make copies of the accounts kept by the HKEC under this Part. (Amended 41 of 2021 s. 85)
An authorized person must, on request, produce a copy of the written authorization when performing the authorized functions.

subsection.leadIn: Except in the performance of any function under this Ordinance or for carrying into effect the provisions of this Ordinance, a specified person—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: must not suffer or permit any person to have access to any matter relating to the affairs of any person that comes to the specified person’s knowledge in the performance of any function under this Ordinance; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: must not communicate any such matter to any person other than the person to whom such matter relates.

subsection.leadIn: Despite subsection (1), a specified person may—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: disclose information that has already been made available to the public;

paragraph.name: b
c
paragraph.content: disclose information for the purpose of seeking advice from, or giving advice by, counsel, or a solicitor, or other professional adviser, acting or proposing to act in a professional capacity in connection with any matter arising under this Ordinance;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: disclose information in connection with any judicial or other proceedings to which the specified person is a party; and

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: disclose information in accordance with an order of a court, magistrate or tribunal, or in accordance with a law or a requirement made under a law.

subsection.leadIn: Despite subsection (1), the AFRC may— (Amended 3 of 2019 s. 63; 41 of 2021 s. 86)

paragraph.name: a
b
paragraph.leadIn: subject to subsection (4), disclose information to—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: the Chief Executive;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: the Financial Secretary;

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: the Secretary for Justice;

subparagraph.name: iv
subparagraph.content: the Secretary for Financial Services and the Treasury;

subparagraph.name: v
subparagraph.content: the Commissioner of Police of Hong Kong;

subparagraph.name: vi
subparagraph.content: the Commissioner of the Independent Commission Against Corruption;

subparagraph.name: vii
subparagraph.content: the Commissioner of Inland Revenue;

subparagraph.name: viii
subparagraph.content: the Registrar of Companies;

subparagraph.name: ix
subparagraph.content: the Official Receiver in a capacity other than that of a liquidator or provisional liquidator appointed under, or holding such office by virtue of, the Companies (Winding Up and Miscellaneous Provisions) Ordinance (Cap. 32); (Amended 28 of 2012 ss. 912 & 920)

subparagraph.name: x
subparagraph.content: the Monetary Authority;

subparagraph.name: xi
subparagraph.content: the Securities and Futures Commission;

subparagraph.name: xii
xiii
subparagraph.content: the Insurance Authority;

subparagraph.name: xiv
subparagraph.content: the Mandatory Provident Fund Schemes Authority;

subparagraph.name: xv
subparagraph.content: the HKICPA;

subparagraph.name: xvi
subparagraph.content: an inspector appointed by the Financial Secretary under section 142 or 143 of the relevant Ordinance or section 840 or 841 of the Companies Ordinance (Cap. 622) to investigate the affairs of a corporation; (Amended 28 of 2012 ss. 912 & 920)

subparagraph.name: xvii
subparagraph.content: a public officer authorized by the Secretary for Financial Services and the Treasury under subsection (12); or

subparagraph.name: xviii
subparagraph.content: a recognized exchange company; (Replaced 3 of 2019 s. 63)

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: subject to subsection (4), if there is or has been an investigation under Part 3AA, an investigation under Part 3A concerning any PIE engagement or non-PIE engagement carried out for a listed corporation, or an enquiry under Part 4 concerning a relevant non-compliance in relation to a listed corporation, disclose information on the listed corporation to— (Amended 3 of 2019 s. 63; 41 of 2021 s. 86)

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: the Official Receiver in the capacity of a liquidator or provisional liquidator of the listed corporation appointed under, or holding such office by virtue of, the Companies (Winding Up and Miscellaneous Provisions) Ordinance (Cap. 32); or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.leadIn: any other person who—

subparagraph.name: A
subparagraph.content: is a liquidator or provisional liquidator of the listed corporation appointed under the Companies (Winding Up and Miscellaneous Provisions) Ordinance (Cap. 32); or

subparagraph.name: B
subparagraph.content: acts in a similar capacity in relation to the listed corporation under any law of a place outside Hong Kong; (Amended 28 of 2012 ss. 912 & 920)

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.leadIn: disclose information with the consent of—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: the person from whom the information was obtained or received; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: if the information does not relate to such person, the person to whom it relates;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: disclose information in summary form that is so framed as to prevent particulars relating to any person from being ascertained from it; and

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: disclose information for the purpose of, or in connection with, an audit under section 19.

subsection.leadIn: The AFRC must not disclose information under subsection (3)(a), (b) or (c) unless the AFRC is of the opinion that— (Amended 3 of 2019 s. 63; 41 of 2021 s. 86)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the disclosure will enable or assist the recipient of the information to perform the recipient’s functions; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: it is not contrary to the interest of the investing public or to the public interest that the information should be so disclosed.

subsection.leadIn: Subject to subsection (6), if information is disclosed pursuant to subsection (1), (2) or (3) (other than subsection (2)(a) or (3)(e))—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the person to whom the information is so disclosed; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any other person obtaining or receiving the information from that person,

subsection.continued: must not disclose the information to any other person.

subsection.leadIn: Subsection (5) does not prohibit the person referred to in subsection (5)(a) or (b) from disclosing the information to any other person if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the AFRC consents to the disclosure; (Amended 41 of 2021 s. 86)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the information has already been made available to the public;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the disclosure is for the purpose of seeking advice from, or giving advice by, counsel, or a solicitor, or other professional adviser, acting or proposing to act in a professional capacity in connection with any matter arising under this Ordinance;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: the disclosure is in connection with any judicial or other proceedings to which the person so referred to is a party; or

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: the disclosure is in accordance with an order of a court, magistrate or tribunal, or in accordance with a law or a requirement made under a law.

subsection.leadIn: The AFRC may attach such conditions as it considers appropriate to— (Amended 3 of 2019 s. 63; 41 of 2021 s. 86)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a disclosure of information made by it pursuant to subsection (3); or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a consent granted by it pursuant to subsection (6)(a).

subsection.content: Subsection (1) does not affect the operation of section 13(3) of The Ombudsman Ordinance (Cap. 397) or section 44(8) of the Personal Data (Privacy) Ordinance (Cap. 486).

subsection.leadIn: Any specified person who contravenes subsection (1) commits an offence and is liable—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: on conviction on indictment to a fine of $1,000,000 and to imprisonment for 2 years; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: on summary conviction to a fine at level 6 and to imprisonment for 6 months.

subsection.leadIn: A person commits an offence if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the person discloses any information in contravention of subsection (5); and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: at the time of the disclosure—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: the person knew, or ought to have known, that the information was previously disclosed to the person or any other person pursuant to subsection (1), (2) or (3) (other than subsection (2)(a) or (3)(e)); and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: the person had no reasonable grounds to believe that subsection (5) does not apply to the person by virtue of subsection (6).

subsection.leadIn: A person who commits an offence under subsection (10) is liable—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: on conviction on indictment to a fine of $1,000,000 and to imprisonment for 2 years; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: on summary conviction to a fine at level 6 and to imprisonment for 6 months.

subsection.content: The Secretary for Financial Services and the Treasury may authorize any public officer as a person to whom information may be disclosed under subsection (3)(b)(xvii).

def.name: SpecifiedPerson
def.leadIn: In this section, specified person (指明人士) means—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the AFRC; (Amended 41 of 2021 s. 86)

paragraph.name: ab
paragraph.content: a CPA inspector, CPA investigator, FR inspector or FR investigator; or (Replaced 41 of 2021 s. 86. Amended L.N. 66 of 2022)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: any person who—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.leadIn: is or has been—

subparagraph.name: A
subparagraph.content: a member of the AFRC, the Investigation Board, a Review Committee or a committee established by the AFRC;

subparagraph.name: B
C
subparagraph.content: a person employed by or assisting a related person of the AFRC; and (Amended 41 of 2021 s. 86)

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: performs or has performed any function under this Ordinance.

subsection.leadIn: Any information on the identity of a relevant person is not admissible in evidence in—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: any proceedings under Part 3C; (Replaced 3 of 2019 s. 64)

paragraph.name: b
c
paragraph.content: any proceedings before a tribunal established by or under an enactment (statutory tribunal); (Replaced 3 of 2019 s. 64)

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: any proceedings under section 41 of the PA Ordinance; or (Replaced 41 of 2021 s. 87)

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: any proceedings before a Disciplinary Committee constituted under section 33(3) of the PA Ordinance as in force immediately before the 2021 Ordinance commencement date (Disciplinary Committee). (Added 41 of 2021 s. 87)

subsection.leadIn: In such proceedings, a witness is not obliged—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to disclose the name or address of a relevant person who is not a witness in those proceedings; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: to state any matter that would lead, or would tend to lead, to discovery of the name or address of a relevant person who is not a witness in those proceedings.

subsection.leadIn: If a book, document or paper that is in evidence, or liable to inspection, in such proceedings contains an entry—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in which a relevant person is named or described; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: that might lead to discovery of a relevant person,

subsection.continued: the Tribunal, the Court of Appeal, the court, the magistrate, the statutory tribunal or the Disciplinary Committee, as the case may be, must cause all such passages to be concealed from view, or to be obliterated, so far as may be necessary to protect the relevant person from discovery. (Amended 3 of 2019 s. 64)

subsection.leadIn: In such proceedings, the Tribunal, the Court of Appeal, the court, the magistrate, the statutory tribunal or the Disciplinary Committee, as the case may be, may, despite subsection (1), (2) or (3), permit inquiry, and require full disclosure, concerning a relevant person if— (Amended 3 of 2019 s. 64; 41 of 2021 s. 87)

paragraph.name: a
b
paragraph.leadIn: in the case of a relevant person falling within paragraph (a) of the definition of relevant person in subsection (6), it is satisfied that the relevant person made a material statement that the relevant person— (Amended 3 of 2019 s. 64)

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: knew or believed to be false; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: did not believe to be true.

subsection.content: This section has effect despite sections 20ZZN, 31A and 47. (Amended 3 of 2019 s. 64)

def.name: RelevantPerson
def.leadIn: In this section, relevant person (有關人士) means—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: an informer who has given information to the AFRC, a CPA investigator, an FR investigator or a Review Committee with respect to an investigation under Part 3AA or 3A or an enquiry under Part 4; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a person who has assisted the AFRC, a CPA investigator, an FR investigator or a Review Committee with respect to such an investigation or enquiry. (Amended 3 of 2019 s. 64; L.N. 66 of 2022)

subsection.leadIn: This section applies to a person who—

paragraph.name: a
